headline: Murad Doubles Down on SPX6900's "Soul Market" Thesis
subheadline: The ex-Goldman trader endorses a philosophical framework for why memecoins are the next multi-trillion dollar asset class. We checked the data.

quotedPost.title: SOUL MARKET > STOCK MARKET
quotedPost.summary: A long-form article arguing markets are undergoing a secular shift in what we value â€” from stocks to community-driven belief assets.

tokenData.recentAction: Rallied 15% from $0.30 to $0.36, then retraced to $0.31

body.text: Murad Mahmudov, the Princeton-educated ex-Goldman trader who coined "Memecoin Supercycle," is back at it. Tonight he endorsed an article by relatively unknown account @FreedomForAeons (1.5K followers) arguing that memecoins represent a secular shift from stock markets to "soul markets" â€” where community belief replaces fundamentals.

Murad's thesis has always been that memecoins are Veblen goods â€” the more irrational the belief, the stronger the asset. His pinned SPX6900 video (3.2M views) lays out 150 reasons it hits $1T. The community is ride-or-die: people are literally DCAing $5/day for 246 straight days.

SPX sits at $0.33 â€” down 85% from ATH. The "soul market" article reads like cope dressed as philosophy. When your biggest endorser is also your biggest holder, the signal is compromised. Reply quality is bot-heavy, and the loudest counter-signal â€” "why does it keep going down?" â€” gets crickets.

Murad's influence is real â€” this post hit 20K views in an hour. But influence â‰  accuracy. He's been wrong on timing before. The SPX6900 community has cult-like conviction, which cuts both ways: diamond hands on the way down, explosive if macro turns. File under "interesting thesis, biased messenger."
